page.title: 10MENDIP DRY STONE WALLS
page.content: Most walls on the Mendips are dry stone walls. Now only a few people can make them. Walls were originally built by farmers who cleared stones from the fields to avoid the stones breaking their ploughs. The walls were built to mark boundaries and provide shelter for stock and crops. In recent years many walls have been lost due to neglect or bulldozing, to make bigger fields for modern machinery. Barbed wire fences and hedges have taken the place of many stone walls. Building dry stone walls is an art and also very slow and expensive. The foundation stones of the walls are laid at least three feet thick and and two stones wide. The gaps between are filled with smaller stones and chippings. "Bonders", stones which almost pass through the wall, help tie the wall together.
